image.altText: A young Aboriginal child with traditional art painted on their body.

props.synopsis: Young leaders have been called upon to "keep our fire burning" as one of the country's largest Aboriginal land councils marks 50 years of fierce advocacy for native title rights.

title.children: Central Land Council celebrates 50 years of 'astonishing' advocacy for land rights

image.altText: An elderly man wearing a military hat and war medals.

props.synopsis: Glenn Dobie served Australia during World War II, but his friends and family later discovered he never received the recognition he was entitled to.

title.children: World War II veteran receives missing service medals nearly 80 years later

image.altText: A woman with blue hair sits at a park.

props.synopsis: Cheryl Rowe never thought she'd spend two years living in a tent, worrying during every winter storm that her shelter would collapse on top of her again.

title.children: At 65, Cheryl has spent the winter 'digging trenches' to stop her tent from flooding

image.altText: Penrith Panthers lift the NRL Premiership trophy

props.synopsis: The Penrith Panthers have won a historic fourth NRL premiership in a row, defeating the Melbourne Storm 14-6 in the grand final.

title.children: Panthers claim historic fourth straight premiership as biting allegation rocks NRL grand final

image.altText: Jack Howarth lies under Panthers players as Storm players celebrate

props.synopsis: Cameron Munster's season ends with allegations he bit a Panther, while the Bunker supported a no-try decision but Melbourne believed footage showed the ball on the ground. Here are the quick hits from the 2024 NRL grand final.

title.children: Grand final quick hits: NRL says bunker made correct call on disallowed try, as Melbourne star is accused of biting

image.altText: Nathan Cleary (right) of the Panthers poses with the Provan-Summons Trophy alongside his father and coach Ivan Cleary

props.synopsis: The Panthers show yet again they are a team that finds joy in the struggle, who like the fight more than they like the win — and they like the win an awful lot.

title.children: Penrith prove that rugby league immortality comes by winning one play at a time

image.altText: Mid shot of a woman and a man addressing the media.

props.synopsis: Against warnings from health, justice and Aboriginal groups, the NT government says it will fulfil its election promise and return the age of criminal responsibility back to 10 this year.

title.children: 'It's going to scar them': NT to become first jurisdiction to lower criminal age of responsibility

image.altText: The front façade of a prison at dusk

props.synopsis: Western Australian taxpayers aren't getting bang for their buck in the area of youth justice, but it's children who are paying the highest price.

title.children: Here's why not investing in youth justice is costing taxpayers more and making everyone less safe

image.altText: A composite image of two men and two women

props.synopsis: One year ago today, Hamas-led terrorists infiltrated southern Israel from Gaza and went on a rampage. In this oral history, survivors recall the deadliest attack on Jews in a single day since the Holocaust.

title.children: 'I told the kids to scream': How Israel's worst day unfolded, told by the people who lived through it

image.altText: An elderly man in a high-vis work shirt leaning on timber frame of his verandah.

props.synopsis: Through mining booms and busts, the Kalgoorlie Nickel Smelter in Western Australia has operated continuously since 1973. But workers are now being stood down as BHP prepares to place its Nickel West division on care and maintenance.

title.children: Graeme reluctantly hangs up his high-vis as nickel smelter marks 'end of an era'

image.altText: A woman with a brown ponytail, jeans and a tshirt stands in front of a freshly painted white and cream Queenslander-style pub

props.synopsis: A historic Queensland hotel which was gutted by fire in 2015 is reopening today thanks to the vision of one enterprising couple who took a chance on country hospitality.

title.children: When Nicole bought her first country pub she 'couldn't even pour a beer' — now she owns three

image.altText: A woman cries and leans on a body that is covered with the Israeli flag.

props.synopsis: October 7 was not just another wave of Middle East violence; it was a massacre and kidnapping so unconscionable and cruel it has radically changed everything. But as we mark this day, a deal for peace seems further away than ever.

title.children: Politicians have warned against protesting today, but their words cannot control the visceral grief of Australians

image.altText: Children at the site of a destroyed building

props.synopsis: An Israeli air strike hit a mosque in Gaza with Palestinian officials saying at least 19 people were killed overnight. Israeli planes also continue to attack the southern suburbs of Beirut. Follow live.

title.children: IDF air strike hits central Gaza mosque as woman killed in shooting attack in southern Israel

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Victim from bus station terror attack was Israeli policewoman
WATCH: Albanese delivers message to mark one-year since October 7 terror attack
Dozens killed in Gaza mosque attack as Israeli army launches new incursion in north

image.altText: A truck drives out of the entrance of the Darwin Port on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The Chinese-controlled Port of Darwin has signed a "friendly cooperation" agreement with Shenzhen Port in southern China, citing a wish to establish a closer relationship and examine business opportunities.

title.children: Darwin Port increases 'friendly cooperation' with China in new deal

image.altText: A woman with grey hair sits in a chair in a house, looking out the window.

props.synopsis: Federal Financial Services Minister Stephen Jones says he wants to stamp out bad behaviour by retirement village operators following an ABC investigation that revealed "legalised financial abuse of the elderly" is rife.

title.children: Retirement villages put on notice after being accused of gouging older Australians in 'corporatised elder abuse'

image.altText: A close up of a man wearing a hoodie with his face blurred as he stares at a computer screen.

props.synopsis: Scammers are targeting Australians in offshore call centres as they're seen as "easy prey", according to a young migrant who used to work in an Ukrainian call centre.

title.children: This young migrant used to work in a call centre. Now he's lifting the lid on how scams work

image.altText: Angus Taylor

props.synopsis: Gus Taylor's long climb back after amputation and an accidental death.

title.children: Millsy died on his first rock climb. But he saved Gus's life

image.altText: A man walking with cows.

props.synopsis: An increasing number of Chinese youths fed up with the pressures and values of urban life are moving to China's vast countryside and transforming it in their own ways.

title.children: 'People realise you don't have to work at a desk': China's young people are heading for the hills

image.altText: Early morning sun shining through steam clouds billowing from a nuclear power plant.

props.synopsis: As Australia considers the possibility of a nuclear-powered future, the US gives us insights into what does, and doesn't, work.

title.children: Peter Dutton says this is the kind of nuclear reactor Australia needs. How is it working for the US?

image.altText: A group of Aboriginal men of varying ages standing in a park.

props.synopsis: Inspired by a Sydney men's walking group, Ngiyampaa man Anthony Hayward started one in Broken Hill as a safe space to discuss men's business and inspire future generations.

title.children: Outback Indigenous walking group getting men's health 'on the right track' step by step

image.altText: A sinking ship.

props.synopsis: New Zealand says it has rescued all 75 crew and passengers from a wrecked navy vessel that ran aground and sank off Samoa while conducting a reef survey.

title.children: New Zealand navy ship runs aground and sinks off Samoa

image.altText: Jasmine Fleming celebrates a Hawks AFLW goal against Dockers.

props.synopsis: Hawthorn defender Mackenzie Eardley is sent to hospital during the Hawks' nine-point win over Fremantle, while Essendon earns a hard-fought victory over Gold Coast, and Geelong pips the Sydney Swans.

title.children: Injury-hit Hawks claim brave victory as Bombers, Cats chalk up wins

image.altText: Brooke Anderson of the Sharks holding her head in her hands, sitting, after her team loses the grand final

props.synopsis: The Sharks fought their way off the canvas just enough to inspire a dream of the greatest comeback in women's rugby league history, only for the Roosters to steady when it counted most.

title.children: Cronulla Sharks fall short of impossible comeback against Sydney Roosters, compounding pain of grand final defeat

image.altText: woman standing at cafe

props.synopsis: Helene Newson created the free flatmate-finding event after being forced into shared housing because she could no longer afford to live on her own.

title.children: Older women 'speed dating' for a place to live amid rental crisis

image.altText: Trumpie

props.synopsis: Donald Trump returns to Pennsylvania, where he was nearly assassinated in July, holding a rally with heightened security and guest Elon Musk.

title.children: 'We've bled together': Trump returns to site of Pennsylvania assassination attempt with Elon Musk

image.altText: A child sits next to a sandy crater

props.synopsis: With the first anniversary of the October 7 attacks on Israel looming, we ask a wide range of experts in the Middle East how the current crisis ends.

title.children: 'A genuine turning point in the Middle East': A year after the October 7 attacks, everything has changed

image.altText: the gabba stadium

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader David Crisafulli suggests a rebuild or upgrade of the Gabba would be "part of the mix" of a planned Olympics review to be ordered by an LNP government.

title.children: Queensland LNP leaves the door open to Gabba rebuild ahead of state election

image.altText: A pub at night time

props.synopsis: Twenty-one years ago, the tiny town of Ultima set out to boost its population by 25 per cent within a year at a cost of just $12.

title.children: This tiny Australian town sold abandoned plots of land for $1 to boost its dwindling population

image.altText: A man wearing glasses smiles while sitting at a shop counter surrounded by books.

props.synopsis: Attempted book bans, drag storytime protests and a changing customer base are just some of the challenges facing Australia's LGBTQ+ bookshops as they strive to maintain their radical legacy.

title.children: 'Homosexuality was illegal when we opened': The importance of queer bookshops

image.altText: Departure/arrival signs at the entrance to Melbourne Airport.

props.synopsis: Assistant Minister for Immigration Matt Thistlethwaite has offered a scathing assessment of Australia's approach to immigration. A lot rides on the government's efforts to re-establish bipartisanship, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Immigration has provided 'marginal economic benefit', says the assistant minister. A lot rides on what happens next

image.altText: A male artist with bleached blonde hair and beanie sits on couch with large green octopus toy and holds his artworks

props.synopsis: Dyscalculia, which Alfie Barker describes as being like "dyslexia but for maths", receives only a fraction of the research funding its literacy counterpart does, and experts believe that needs to change.

title.children: Tasmanian artist Alfie Barker has 'dyslexia but for maths', which means he cannot drive

image.altText: A composite of Kamala Harris and Cate Blanchet.

props.synopsis: Across Australia, households on six figure incomes are struggling to pay the rent or mortgages – let alone afford little luxuries. Others are delaying retirement or working extra jobs to pay the bills.

title.children: If Kamala Harris and Cate Blanchett call themselves middle class, where does that leave the rest of us?

image.altText: Close up photo of man with grey hair smiling

props.synopsis: A 27-year-old man has appeared in a Perth court charged with murdering his father at a regional roadhouse.

title.children: 'An amazing man': Tributes flow for man allegedly killed by son at Salmon Gums roadhouse

image.altText: A five year old girl being hugged passionately by her mother

props.synopsis: On a quiet October day in 1972, Victoria Police faced the unthinkable when six students and a teacher were kidnapped from a country school. Now one of the survivors is sharing her story.

title.children: 'Crime of the century' survivor breaks silence 52 years after Faraday school kidnapping
